### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I don't know where else this could extend to.  Running powershell v7.2.5-1 on Fedora the dot-slash ( ./ ) file path relative reference does not resolve the the current path in the running powershell process.  Instead, it refers to the path where 'pwsh' was executed from.

This was observed with using the CopyTo() and MoveTo() methods on an object assigned to a variable using Get-Item and Get-ChildItem

### Expected behavior

```console
LinuxPrompt /> mkdir /testPath1
LinuxPrompt /> mkdir /testPath2
LinuxPrompt /> touch /testPath1/testFile.txt
LinuxPrompt /> cd /testPath1
LinuxPrompt /testPath1/> pwsh
PowerShell 7.2.5
Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation.

https://aka.ms/powershell
Type 'help' to get help.

PS /testPath1> cd /testPath2
PS /testPath2> $FILE = Get-Item /testPath1/testFile.txt
PS /testPath2> $FILE.CopyTo("./testFile-COPY.txt")

UnixMode   User             Group                 LastWriteTime           Size Name
--------   ----             -----                 -------------           ---- ----
                                                6/28/2022 17:37                testFile-COPY.txt

PS /testPath2> $FILE.MoveTo("./testFile-MOVE.txt")
PS /testPath2> Get-ChildItem

    Directory: /testPath2

UnixMode   User             Group                 LastWriteTime           Size Name
--------   ----             -----                 -------------           ---- ----
-rw-r--r-- root             root                6/28/2022 17:37              0 testFile-COPY.txt
-rw-r--r-- root             root                6/28/2022 17:37              0 testFile-MOVE.txt

PS /testPath2> Get-ChildItem /testPath1/
PS /testPath2>
```


### Actual behavior

```console
LinuxPrompt /> mkdir /testPath1
LinuxPrompt /> mkdir /testPath2
LinuxPrompt /> touch /testPath1/testFile.txt
LinuxPrompt /> cd /testPath1
LinuxPrompt /testPath1/> pwsh
PowerShell 7.2.5
Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation.

https://aka.ms/powershell
Type 'help' to get help.

PS /testPath1> cd /testPath2
PS /testPath2> $FILE = Get-Item /testPath1/testFile.txt
PS /testPath2> $FILE.CopyTo("./testFile-COPY.txt")

UnixMode   User             Group                 LastWriteTime           Size Name
--------   ----             -----                 -------------           ---- ----
                                                6/28/2022 17:37                testFile-COPY.txt

PS /testPath2> $FILE.MoveTo("./testFile-MOVE.txt")
PS /testPath2> Get-ChildItem
PS /testPath2>
PS /testPath2> Get-ChildItem /testPath1/

    Directory: /testPath1

UnixMode   User             Group                 LastWriteTime           Size Name
--------   ----             -----                 -------------           ---- ----
-rw-r--r-- root             root                6/28/2022 17:37              0 testFile-COPY.txt
-rw-r--r-- root             root                6/28/2022 17:37              0 testFile-MOVE.txt

PS /testPath2>
```

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
Yep. The `.CopyTo()` and `.MoveTo()` methods originate from the .NET objects. PowerShell has a separate concept of "current directory" to .NET, mainly because PowerShell's current directory can differ on a per-thread (per-Runspace) basis, so there can be multiple "current directories" in use by a single PowerShell instance.

.NET's methods do not really allow PowerShell to inject its current runspace directory into the process-wide current directory in a way that can avoid race conditions (in other words, the behaviour would be unpredictable at best if PowerShell tried to do this). Additionally, PowerShell's provider subsystem can mean the "current directory" is not even on the filesystem at all, and so would be useless for .NET methods that expect to be working with a filesystem path.

As a result, whenever calling .NET methods (even on objects received from a PowerShell cmdlet) you need to fully qualify or resolve any paths you're using first. You can use `Resolve-Path` to do this before passing the path to the .NET method, or if you're working at the command line, you can usually tab-complete paths to expand them to their fully qualified representation.

This is a design limitation of the way PowerShell is built, as far as I know.
